conclusion: Analyze step-by-step whether light b will first undergo total internal reflection.
The figure shows an equilateral triangular glass prism with two monochromatic light beams (a and b) entering perpendicular to the hypotenuse.
After entering the prism, these beams will reach other faces and potentially exit the prism or undergo total internal reflection.
Two different monochromatic lights (a and b) enter the glass prism.
Both enter perpendicular to the hypotenuse (so no refraction at entry).
Both will have the same angle of incidence when exiting the glass to air.
Determine which beam will first undergo total internal reflection when the angle of incidence is gradually increased.
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle depends on the refractive indices of the media and is given by sin(theta_c) = n2/n1.
theta_c is the critical angle, n1 is the refractive index of the medium the light is in (glass), n2 is the refractive index of the medium the light is going to (air).
Since a and b are different monochromatic lights, they have different wavelengths.
The refractive index of glass varies with wavelength - this is called dispersion.
Generally, shorter wavelengths (like blue/violet) experience a higher refractive index than longer wavelengths (like red).
For beam a with refractive index n_a, the critical angle is sin(theta_c,a) = n_air/n_a.
For beam b with refractive index n_b, the critical angle is sin(theta_c,b) = n_air/n_b.
The beam with the smaller critical angle will undergo total internal reflection first when the angle of incidence is gradually increased.
If n_b > n_a, then sin(theta_c,b) < sin(theta_c,a), which means theta_c,b < theta_c,a.
From the figure and the statement that 'light b will first undergo total internal reflection,' we can infer that light b must have a higher refractive index than light a.
Light b must have a shorter wavelength than light a.
The statement 'light b will first undergo total internal reflection' is correct if light b has a shorter wavelength than light a.
